description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pain& Central Nervous System Daily News-- Investigators publish new report on Genetic Diseases and Conditions- Tuberous Sclerosis. According to news reporting from Milan, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,“ Lymphangioleiomyiomatosis is a rare disease affecting women in childbearing age.
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pain & Central
Nervous System Daily News \-- Investigators publish new report on Genetic
Diseases and Conditions - Tuberous Sclerosis. According to news reporting from
Milan, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,
"Lymphangioleiomyiomatosis (LAM) is a rare disease affecting women in
childbearing age. A sporadic form (S-LAM) affecting previously healthy women,
and a form associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC-LAM) are
described."

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University
of Milano, "Some data suggested that TSC-LAM could be a milder disease
compared to S-LAM. To investigate whether the different disease behavior is
real or due to overdiagnosis of screened TSC women, we compared the natural
history of S-LAM and TSC-LAM in patients with incidental diagnosis. Clinical,
and functional data from 52 patients (23 with S-LAM and 29 with TSC-LAM) were
analysed. At diagnosis functional impairment was mild without differences
between groups [FEV1 % pred was 97% (88-105) and 94% (82-106) in TSC-LAM and
S-LAM, respectively, p=0.125]. Patients with S-LAM had less renal
angiomyolipoma, and lower VEGF-D serum levels than TSC-LAM. There was no
difference in the baseline extent of pulmonary cysts on CT scan and no
difference in yearly rate of functional decline between TSC-LAM, and S-LAM
patients [e.g. yearly rate of decline of FEV1 % pred was -0.51 (-1.59-2.24)
and -0.90 (-1.92--0.42) in TSC-LAM and S-LAM, respectively, p=0.265]."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The natural history
of TSC-LAM and S-LAM, when a potential selection bias due to screening in the
latter group is balanced, is similar. Our study suggests that the prevalence
of S-LAM can be significantly underestimated due to a tendency to diagnosis
more frequently patients with more severe impairment, without identifying
several ones with asymptomatic disease."

For more information on this research see: Natural history of incidental
sporadic and tuberous sclerosis complex associated lymphangioleiomyomatosis.
_Respiratory Medicine_ , 2020;168():105993. _Respiratory Medicine_ can be
contacted at: W B Saunders Co LTD, 32 Jamestown Rd, London NW1 7BY, England.
(Elsevier \- [www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Respiratory Medicine
- <http://www.journals.elsevier.com/respiratory-medicine/>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting F. Di Marco, Dept. of Health Sciences, University of Milano, Milan,
Italy. Additional authors for this research include S. Terraneo, O.M. Dias, G.
Imeri, S. Centanni, R.F. Rinaldo, L. Giuliani, E. Lesma, G. Palumbo, M.
Wanderley, C.R. Ribeiro Carvalho and B. Guedes Baldi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rmed.2020.105993>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal _Respiratory Medicine_ is: W B
Saunders Co LTD, 32 Jamestown Rd, London NW1 7BY, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Findings from University of Milano Provide New Insights into Tuberous Sclerosis (Natural history of incidental sporadic and tuberous sclerosis complex associated lymphangioleiomyomatosis): Genetic Diseases and Conditions - Tuberous Sclerosis
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pain & Central Nervous System Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on Genetic Diseases and Conditions - Tuberous Sclerosis. According to news reporting from Milan, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Lymphangioleiomyiomatosis (LAM) is a rare disease affecting women in childbearing age. A sporadic form (S-LAM) affecting previously healthy women, and a form associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC-LAM) are described.”

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Milano, “Some data suggested that TSC-LAM could be a milder disease compared to S-LAM. To investigate whether the different disease behavior is real or due to overdiagnosis of screened TSC women, we compared the natural history of S-LAM and TSC-LAM in patients with incidental diagnosis. Clinical, and functional data from 52 patients (23 with S-LAM and 29 with TSC-LAM) were analysed. At diagnosis functional impairment was mild without differences between groups [FEV1 % pred was 97% (88-105) and 94% (82-106) in TSC-LAM and S-LAM, respectively, p=0.125]. Patients with S-LAM had less renal angiomyolipoma, and lower VEGF-D serum levels than TSC-LAM. There was no difference in the baseline extent of pulmonary cysts on CT scan and no difference in yearly rate of functional decline between TSC-LAM, and S-LAM patients [e.g. yearly rate of decline of FEV1 % pred was -0.51 (-1.59-2.24) and -0.90 (-1.92--0.42) in TSC-LAM and S-LAM, respectively, p=0.265].”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The natural history of TSC-LAM and S-LAM, when a potential selection bias due to screening in the latter group is balanced, is similar. Our study suggests that the prevalence of S-LAM can be significantly underestimated due to a tendency to diagnosis more frequently patients with more severe impairment, without identifying several ones with asymptomatic disease.”

For more information on this research see: Natural history of incidental sporadic and tuberous sclerosis complex associated lymphangioleiomyomatosis. Respiratory Medicine, 2020;168():105993. Respiratory Medicine can be contacted at: W B Saunders Co LTD, 32 Jamestown Rd, London NW1 7BY, England. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Respiratory Medicine - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/respiratory-medicine/)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting F. Di Marco, Dept. of Health Sciences, University of Milano, Milan, Italy. Additional authors for this research include S. Terraneo, O.M. Dias, G. Imeri, S. Centanni, R.F. Rinaldo, L. Giuliani, E. Lesma, G. Palumbo, M. Wanderley, C.R. Ribeiro Carvalho and B. Guedes Baldi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rmed.2020.105993. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal Respiratory Medicine is: W B Saunders Co LTD, 32 Jamestown Rd, London NW1 7BY, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
